titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Yale Cabaret Records
titlestmt.author: compiled by Daniel Hartwig

p.extref: Copyright Â© 2012 by the Yale University Library.

note.p: This encoded finding aid is compliant with the Yale EAD Best Practice Guidelines, Version 1.0.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit

did.head: Overview
did.abstract: The materials consist of photographs, press material, posters, meeting minutes, programs and other materials documenting the management, activities, and productions of the Yale Cabaret.

note.label: Note:
note.p: Forms part of Yale Record Group 22-E (YRG 22-E), Records of departments, offices, programs, and projects of the Yale School of Drama.).

acqinfo.p: The records were transferred from the Yale Cabaret, 2008

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the materials is restricted. See Collection Contents for details.

userestrict.head: Ownership Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for materials authored or otherwise produced as official business of Yale University is retained by Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Yale Cabaret Records (RU 1075). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Notes
processinfo.p: Yale University records are arranged and described at the accession level by the creating office. The University Archives creates collection level descriptive records, but typically does no further arrangement and description at the accession level.

bioghist.head: Information about the Creator(s)
bioghist.p: The Yale Cabaret was established in 1968 in the old Phi Gamma Alpha fraternity house (217 Park St) as a coffee shop with the purpose of doing "experimental work" and providing a space for guest artists, faculty, and students to perform. On November 8, 1968, the Cabaret opened is doors with its first performance by Alvin Epstein and Martha Schlamme, singing the songs of Kurt Weill.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Papers
scopecontent.p: The materials consist of photographs, press material, posters, meeting minutes, programs and other materials documenting the management, activities, and productions of the Yale Cabaret.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged by accession.

did.unittitle: Dancing on the Edge of the World
The Love of Don Perlimplin and Belisa in the Garden
Sherlock Holmes and The Adventures of Making Whoopee
Might as Well Be Spring, or Bill Clinton Goes to the Bathroom
Finding Ways to Prove You're Not an Al-Qaeda Terrorist When You're Brown
